body: THE 1887 Emmanuel Baptist Church, at 279 Lafayette Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, has one of New York's most spectacular church interiors, a rich mixture of stained glass, wood and elaborate stencilwork. Early next year the church, whose congregation has changed over the years from white to predominantly black, will begin to
title: Streetscapes / The Emmanuel Baptist Church in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; An Offshoot Founded by an Offended Millionaire

body: To the Editor: Your article raised important issues, but it suffers from a glaring omission: not one quote from a working tour guide or bus driver or hotel concierge or anyone else who works with tourists day in and day out. As a tour guide, I am constantly urging visitors to get off the beaten track and see the city's less crowded treasures,
title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides

body: With the smell of simmering collard greens in the air, Thomas W. Bayley Jr. sat at the counter of a soul food diner in the South Bronx on a recent morning and launched into a nonstop recitation of the history of black candidates in the Republican Party. ''The Republican Party started as the party that was against slavery,'' said Mr. Bayley, a
title: Uphill Racers of New York City Politics; For a Variety of Reasons, Underdogs Persevere in the Face of Almost Sure Defeat

body: Federal agents executing a search warrant at a Brooklyn house last night exchanged gunfire with five men, killing one before the other four surrendered early this morning, the police said. Agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the Drug Enforcement Administration knocked on the door of 42 Wallworth Street near Park Avenue in
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Man Killed in Shootout With Agents in Brooklyn

body: The news that a woman had been raped this weekend aboard a G train operated without a conductor shocked women riding the line yesterday -- but the assault was not the only source of their dismay. ''I thought every train had a conductor on it,'' said a passenger, Carol Johnson, as she waited yesterday for the G train at the Smith-Ninth Streets
title: Subway Rape Raises Concern About Reduced Train Crews

body: IF you ever wanted to explore your neighbor's garden, now is your chance, as 24 private gardens and 13 community gardens open their gates to the public today for a self-guided tour. The gardens are in Fort Greene (including the one shown here), Clinton Hill and Prospect Heights. On view, among other things, will be a re-creation of the Long Island
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; Cultivated Brooklyn

body: PRATT INSTITUTE in Brooklyn, founded in 1887 by Charles Pratt, one of John D. Rockefeller's partners, started out as a trade and art school in a hodgepodge of factorylike buildings. But recent projects at the venerable institution seek to give more of a collegiate air to what was for a long time a largely urban campus. Born in 1830, Charles Pratt
title: Streetscapes/Pratt Institute, Brooklyn; A Venerable Campus in a Largely Urban Mode

body: THE sounds of hammers banging, guidebooks rustling and choruses of ''Such exquisite woodwork!'' and ''Are those perennials?'' are in the air. This is the season for house and garden tours, most of them benefits for preservation groups, schools or social-service organizations. All tours are self-guided unless otherwise indicated. title: The Surest Sign Of Spring: Tours

body: The Rev. Samuel Austin, pastor of Brown Memorial Baptist Church of Brooklyn and a leader in his 8.5-million member denomination, the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., died last Friday in Los Angeles. He was 62 and lived in Brooklyn. He had attended the midwinter board meeting of the convention, the nation's largest black denomination, and
title: Samuel Austin, 62, a Pastor and Baptist Leader

body: LAUREN GLANT gazed at the contents of a small plastic container as if they were diamonds. ''Eggshells,'' she said proudly. Very old eggshells, she said, mixed with a little bit of ash, that she had helped unearth from a cistern in her backyard at 35 Wyckoff Avenue in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn. Chances are they landed there sometime in the
title: Habitats/35 Wyckoff Avenue, Boerum Hill; Digging Up History
